dropbear-ssh-on-keenetic-login-without-p.title: Dropbear ssh on Keenetic login without password
dropbear-ssh-on-keenetic-login-without-p.description:
Yes, you can use a different key for testing without needing to delete the current key from either machine. Hereâ€™s how you can do it:If you don't already have a new key, you can generate one using:1ssh-keygen -t rsa -f "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\Your_KeyName"1ssh-keygen -t rsa -b 4096 -f "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\Your_KeyName"This will create a new private key (Your_KeyName) and a corresponding public key (Your_KeyName.pub) in your .ssh directory. -b 4096 specifies the key length (in bits), with 4096 being a stronger, more secure choice. -f specifies the filename where the private key will be stored. The shorter command will create the file with the default name id_rsa in C:\Users\UserName\.ssh folder:1ssh-keygen -t rsa with 2048 bit (standard, but lower security) Agent work only in the current session! If you want to start it on every session, you need to start it as a service. Skip this the following steps, and follow this instruction: Auto-start SSH Agent on every terminal session If you want to start the Agent temporary, follow the steps: Start the Agent, if it isn't started: 1eval $(ssh-agent) You can add the new key to the SSH agent without affecting the current key: 1ssh-add "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_rsa"This tells the SSH agent to use the new private key for authentication.1type ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub | ssh root@192.168.1.1 -p 222 "cat >> /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys && chmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbear && chmod 600 /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys" chmod 600 /opt/etc/dropbear/authorized_keys â€” 600 is the required permission for authorized_keys hmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbear â€” 700 is the required permission for the folder.
You might need to create it, though. Login to root@192.168.1.1, and do the following:1mkdir /opt/etc/dropbear && chmod 700 /opt/etc/dropbearTo check that it's created, use:1ls -a /opt/etc/dropbear1icacls C:\Users\maxpe\.ssh\dropbear_rsa_hostkey /grant "MAKSIM\maxpe:F" /inheritance:r If it didn't work:
Windows â€” Remove permissions from the file If you used the SSH agent, it will automatically use it:1ssh -v root@192.168.1.1 -p 222Or, if you prefer to manually specify the key without adding it to the agent:1ssh -v -i "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_rsa" root@192.168.1.1 -p 222 -v argument stands for "verbose" â€” it's showing you the log You do not have to delete the old key from either machine. Both the old key and the new key can be used independently. Dropbear will try to authenticate with whichever key is available on the client-side (via the SSH agent or specified with the -i flag).This allows you to test with a new key while keeping your original key intact. When youâ€™re ready to switch back to the old key, you can either: Remove the new key from the SSH agent using ssh-add -d "$env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\new_key", or Simply specify the old key manually again. Let me know if you'd like more guidance!
Key-based authentication in OpenSSH for Windows | Microsoft Learn â€” Note the part about non-English localized versions of the operating systemand this can give an idea to create a variable: 1# Get the public key file generated previously on your client2$authorizedKey = Get-Content -Path $env:USERPROFILE\.ssh\id_ecdsa.pub34# Generate the PowerShell to be run remote that will copy the public key file generated previously on your client to the authorized_keys file on your server5$remotePowershell = "powershell Add-Content -Force -Path $env:ProgramData\ssh\administrators_authorized_keys -Value '''$authorizedKey''';icacls.exe ""$env:ProgramData\ssh\administrators_authorized_keys"" /inheritance:r /grant ""Administrators:F"" /grant ""SYSTEM:F"""67# Connect to your server and run the PowerShell using the $remotePowerShell variable8ssh username@domain1@contoso.com $remotePowershell

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_siteName.description: The name of the vault / exported site

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
